summary: This is a court order by Judge Alison J. Nathan granting a short continuance of Ghislaine Maxwell's trial from July 2021 to fall 2021. The continuance is granted due to the government's late filing of a superseding indictment (S2) which added new charges and an alleged victim, requiring additional defense preparation time. The order balances the defense's need to prepare against the interests of a speedy trial.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, whose defense counsel requested a continuance of the trial date due to a new superseding indictment.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The United States District Judge who issued the order granting a continuance of Maxwell's trial to fall 2021.

persons.name: Judge Furman
persons.context: A judge presiding over a separate criminal matter involving lawyers who are also involved in the Maxwell case, mentioned in the context of a scheduling conflict.

connections.description: Judge Nathan is presiding over the criminal case against defendant Maxwell and issued the order regarding her trial schedule.

events.title: Filing of S2 Superseding Indictment
events.description: The Government filed a superseding indictment (S2) adding new charges and identifying a fourth alleged victim, extending the timeframe of alleged conspiracies.

events.title: Original Trial Start Date
events.description: The trial was originally scheduled to commence on this date before being adjourned.

events.title: Deadline for Joint Trial Date Proposal
events.description: The parties are ordered to meet and confer and jointly propose a new trial start date for fall 2021 by this date.

locations: UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT SOUTHERN DISTRICT OF NEW YORK
keyFacts: The S2 Superseding Indictment added significant new charges against Ghislaine Maxwell, including a sex trafficking conspiracy (2001-2004) and sex trafficking of a minor (Counts 5 & 6).
The S2 indictment extended the timeframe of the alleged conspiracies from through 1997 to 2004 and identified a fourth alleged victim, referred to as 'Minor Victim-4'.
Judge Alison J. Nathan granted a continuance of the trial from July 2021 to fall 2021, rejecting both the defense's request for a January 2022 date and the government's proposal for March 2022.
The court cited the COVID-19 pandemic as hampering defense preparation due to travel constraints and safety concerns.
The order emphasizes the need to balance the defense's preparation time against the defendant's pre-trial detention status and the public/victims' interest in a trial without undue delay.
